text: Nostradamus decoded Nostradamus knew
what people wanted his first book was a
popular cosmetics guide and cookbook
then he hit on a winning combination he
realized that there was a large market
in doing almanacs and that the almanacs
had plenty of rather vague and rather
entertaining sounding predictions in
them then they would sell better so this
was a very popular idea
Nostradamus jumped into it with both
feet the almanacs employed basic
astronomy predicting the hours of
daylight the weather and the planting
calendars but he drew on all his skills
and added a touch of astrology in 16th
century Europe they didn't have anything
like the distinctive divisions in fields
like we have astronomy versus astrology
chemistry versus alchemy these are all
just blended into what was called
natural philosophy therefore he had all
the tools the intellectual tools and the
cultural context to do what what he did
better than most other people
Nostradamus put his classical education
to good use peppering is writing with
dark illusions cryptic symbolism and a
heavy dose of doom and gloom what he did
was he added the idea of adding a little
prophecy to it jazzing it up as it were
talking about two-headed monsters and
what they might mean and and this gave
everybody a little bit of excitement it
was the ultimate sales formula
poles laced with astrology with
carefully constructed language that
implied a look into the future it was a
formula for success in the 16th century
we have the printing press but still not
everything was written down if you put
it in verse you can memorize it so much
more effectively and it has a kind of
rhythmic effect on the mind and it
becomes more compelling as well
